entry.title: Q2 2025 Wrap up - SAP Columbus group
entry.content:
In Quarter 2 of the year 2025 we had two meetups. We conducted both a physical gathering and a virtual one. Both were successful. A total of 12 members have joined the Columbus group so far. Many new SAP Community Network logins are being created. Everyone has shown a positive response so far. Here is the wrap-up post of Q2.

In the first physical meetup we had, we discussed the emerging trends in the utility industry and the pharma industry. We discussed the work people were doing in various projects. @manish1910  talked about emerging trends in the pharma industry. In our group, there are a few end users who are eager to transition their careers into core SAP consulting jobs. We got @PawanKhatri , who sponsored the first physical meetup by providing a meeting room and lunch for the members. Overall we got a fantastic start for our Columbus group.

Here is our first meetup photograph:

The second meetup was virtual, where we discussed a specific topic on the SAP S4HANA trial. The request came from @RajeevShah. We discussed details about S4HANA trial access and gave a demo online. @Priyanka_Mishra also joined the virtual meetup and shared her project experience in S4HANA.

We are looking forward to our next meetup soon in July 2025.

Regards,

Vaibhav Mishra

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Tokyo 2025 chillSAP × JSUG Next-Gen Boost 若手LT大会開催！
entry.content:
こんにちは、chillSAP運営チームです。

イベントでの登壇、チャレンジしてみたいけど、ちょっとハードル高い…
そう思っている若手のみなさん、その第一歩を踏み出してみませんか？

ひさびさにやります！
若手のためのLT大会！

 

イベントの目的

SAP Inside Track Tokyo などの大きなイベントでは、ベテランの登壇者が多くて少し気後れしてしまう…
そんなSAPに関わる若手メンバーが、気軽に発信・登壇できる場を作りたい！
と思って企画したのがこの若手限定LTイベントです。

そして今回は、JSUG Next-Gen Boostとの共同開催です！さらに盛り上がること間違いなし！

 

️イベント概要

  • 日時：2025/9/19（金） 18:30～

  • 会場：株式会社シグマクシス コラボレーションスペース
    〒105-0001 東京都港区虎ノ門４丁目１−２８ 13F
    マップ：https://www.sigmaxyz.com/ja/company/about.html

  • 対象：SAPに関わる若手メンバー（登壇も視聴参加も歓迎！）& SAPにかかわるベテランメンバー（見守って！）

  • 登壇形式：LT形式（5〜10分程度の発表）

  • 定員：登壇者 8名　参加者 30名

 

まずは登壇者を大募集！

「話してみたい！」と思ったその気持ちが、SAPコミュニティをもっと面白くします。
内容はSAPに関わることであれば、なんでもOK！
ツールの使い方、プロジェクトの工夫、勉強法、ちょっとした失敗談まで。
お気軽にエントリーしてください！

  • 発表形式：LT（5〜10分のライトトーク）

  • 発表テーマ例：

    • 「SAP BTP 初めてやってみた」
    • 「若手視点で見たSAPの○○」
    • 「こんなとき、どうしてる？業務の小ネタ」

📮登壇希望の方はこちら（リンク）からお申し込みください！

 

スペシャルゲスト

また、今回のイベントでは、

✨グローバルSAP Communityで"SAP Champion"に選出された tamiさん をゲストにお迎えします！

SAP Champion 紹介ページ

普段からtamiさんの発信に助けられている私たち、
SAP Champion かっこいいー！おめでとうございます！
の気持ちから、ぜひお祝いの場を作りたいと思い、お呼びしました。

そして、普段から気になっていた

  • どうしてそんなに発信できるの？
  • キャッチアップの時間ってどうやって確保しているの？
  • そもそもSAP Championってどうやってなるの？

といったことについてお聞きできたらな、と思っています。（※詳細はこれからご相談予定）

 

タイムテーブル（仮）

※これからちゃんと決めます！

時間 内容
18:30受付開始
19:00オープニング・趣旨説明
19:10LT①〜⑤（各5〜10分）
19:45スペシャルゲストトーク：tamiさん
20:10LT⑥〜⑧（希望者数に応じて調整）
20:40クロージング・告知など
21:00終了予定

 

こんな方におすすめ！

  • SAP関連の情報発信に興味があるけど、どこから始めていいかわからない
  • 同世代のSAP仲間とつながりたい
  • LTにチャレンジしてみたい
  • SAP Championの話を聞いてみたい！

 

参加者募集

登壇しない方の参加ももちろんOKです！
SAPを使っているけど他の人がどうしているか知りたい、
登壇に興味はあるけどまずは様子を見てみたい、
若手を温かく見守りたい、
そんな方のご参加をお待ちしています。

  • 参加申込フォーム：こちら

  • 費用：無料

  • 参加形式：現地参加

気になる方は、まずはカレンダーに予定の確保をお願いします。
そして、定員もあるのでぜひぜひ早めの申し込みをお願いします。

 

前回の開催レポート

以前（2020年）の「若手LT祭り」の雰囲気を知りたい方はこちら👇
👉SAPなんでもLT祭（若手編）を開催しました

 

さいごに

「話してみたい！」と思った方は、お気軽にご連絡ください。
初心者・初登壇、大歓迎です！

みなさんのご参加、お待ちしています！

entry.title: Blog It Forward - Masashi Otsuka(sumikko)
entry.content:
Please scroll down for the English version.
This post has a lot of pictures so please take a look.

こんにちは、SAP Communityの皆さん！
河原哲也さん @tetsuyakawahara  からご紹介いただき、今回「Blog It Forward」に参加させていただくことになりました。
※Blog It Forwardのことは以前から知っていましたが、まさか自分に回ってくるとは思っていませんでした

この場を借りて、私のSAPとの関わりやコミュニティ活動についてご紹介させていただきます。

 

自己紹介

名前：大塚將司（Masashi Otsuka）
ニックネーム：すみっこ
役割：S/4HANA拡張領域のコンサルタント／開発者
SAP歴：ABAP開発から始まり、現在はSAP BTPやAWSを活用したソリューション開発に従事しています。

2024年には、SAPジャパンより「SAP BTP Champion」として表彰されました。
この賞は、SAP BTPを活用した革新的な取り組みや、コミュニティへの貢献が評価されたものです。

 


人生を変えた2つのきっかけ

私の人生が大きく変わったきっかけは、2つあります。

(1)ブログ「SAPのすみっこ」をはじめ、コミュニティ「chillSAP」を立ち上げたこと


技術的な知見やイベントの記録を発信する中で、思いがけず多くの方に読んでいただけるようになり、社内外から声をかけてもらう機会が増えました。書くことで自分の考えが整理され、発信することで新たな出会いが生まれ、「情報を発信すると情報が集まってくる」「発信は自分を変える力がある」と実感しました。

そして同じようにSNSで発信している人たちと「もっと自由に、もっと楽しくSAPを語れる場を作りたい」という思いから始めたchillSAP。
そこには、年齢も職種も企業も超えて、SAPに関わるあらゆる人が集まりました。
この活動を通じて、本当に多くの人とつながることができ、人生の景色が変わったと感じています。

「chillSAP」は、SAPに関わるすべての人が「ゆるく、楽しく、つながる」ことを目的とした日本発のコミュニティです。
2019年に設立し、現在までに多数のイベントを開催してきました。

イベント：SAPなんでもライトニングトーク祭
SAPに関する話題なら何でもOKの5分間のLT大会。自由な発表スタイルが特徴です。

 

SAP Inside Track Tokyoの開催
2019年からsitTokyoの運営にも携わっています。他国の詳細はあまり把握しきれていないですが、Tokyoはセッション数は世界でもトップクラスなのでは？と思っています。
SAP Inside Track Tokyo 2019 finished a great success #Recap #sitTokyo 
SAP Inside Track Tokyo 2023 
SAP Inside Track Tokyo 2024 イベントサイト 
SAP Inside Track Tokyo 2025 Event Information 

過去動画もYoutubeで公開していますので、ぜひご覧ください。

ちなみに、私もたまに登壇しています。2025年は「ABAP developer capabilities with Joule」をテーマにお話しさせていだきました。よろしければご覧ください。

 

(2)SAP TechEdに参加して刺激的な学びと出会いがあったこと

SAP TechEdは、私にとって技術と人とのつながりを再確認する場です。これまでに複数回参加し、毎回多くの刺激を受けてきました。

2018年
TechEd Las Vegasにブロガーとして初参加
ブログを始めてわずか8か月で、SAPジャパンから招待されて参加。
「まさか自分が」と驚きつつも、現地での体験がその後のキャリアと人生を大きく変えるきっかけに。

2019年
TechEd Las Vegasで「勝手にすみっこNight」開催
自主的に日本人参加者を集めて交流会を開催。企業や立場を超えてつながる場を自ら作り出した経験は、コミュニティ活動の原点のひとつです

2023年
TechEd Bangaloreに現地参加
コロナ後初のオンサイト開催。SAP BuildやAI関連セッションの実践的なデモや現地参加者の熱量に感動。
世界中の開発者と直接交流できたことが、技術的にも人間的にも大きな刺激に。



日本で開催されたSAP TechEd Japanのクロージングセッションでパネリストとして登壇させていただきました

 

2024年
TechEd on Tour @メルボルン（SAUG-x 2024）
空いていて快適な環境で、じっくりとセッションに集中することができました。
SAPジャパンによる日本人向けサポートも充実しており、安心して参加できた。

 

 

 

 

TechEdを通じたモチベーションの再充電
「これがあるから1年頑張れる」と思うほど、TechEdは私にとって心のチャージの場。
SNSやYouTubeで見ていたSAP Communityの有名な皆さんたちのセッションを生で体験できたことは、今でも忘れられません。
私と写真を撮った記憶がある方はいますか？🙋

 

 

 

BIF質問への回答

自分が20歳に戻ったら何を勉強したい？
英語とIT基礎です。これらをしっかりと学ぶべきだったと思っています(いま勉強中です)

両親から学んだベストレッスン
機嫌のいい両親から学んだことは、「自分の機嫌は自分でとる」ということです。

 

次のBlog It Forward参加者

私からは、日本で一緒にコミュニティを運営しているみのさん( @Mino )  にバトンを渡したいと思います。みのさんの知的好奇心の持ち方と信念がブレないところに私は常に刺激をもらっています。
みのさんの BIF ブログを、ぜひお楽しみに！

 

最後に

SAPのすみっこブログから発信を始めて、今では多くの方とつながることができました。これからもコミュニティを盛り上げていきたいと思います。Blog It Forwardにも参加できて光栄です。
ここまで読んでいただき、ありがとうございました！

以下は、私が2018年に初めて社外で登壇した際の写真です




--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hello, SAP Community!

Thanks to the introduction from Mr. Tetsuya Kawahara @tetsuyakawahara  , I’m excited to be participating in the Blog It Forward  initiative.

I’ve known about Blog It Forward for a while, but I never imagined it would come around to me!

I’d like to take this opportunity to share a bit about my involvement with SAP and my activities within the community.

 

About me

Name: Masashi Otsuka
Nickname: Sumikko
Role: Consultant/Developer in the S/4HANA Extension Area
SAP Experience: I started with ABAP development and am currently engaged in solution development utilizing SAP BTP and AWS.

In 2024, I was honored by SAP Japan as an SAP BTP Champion.
This award recognizes innovative initiatives leveraging SAP BTP and contributions to the community.

 


Two Turning Points That Changed My Life

There are two major turning points that significantly changed the course of my life.

(1) Starting the blog “SAP Sumikko” and launching the community “chillSAP”

 

While sharing technical insights and event recaps through my blog, I was pleasantly surprised to find that many people started reading it. This led to more opportunities to connect with others, both inside and outside my company. Writing helped me organize my thoughts, and sharing them brought new encounters. I came to truly realize that “sharing information attracts more information” and “sharing has the power to transform you.”

Inspired by others who were also actively sharing on social media, I launched chillSAP with the desire to create a space where people could talk about SAP more freely and enjoyably.

chillSAP brought together people from all backgrounds—regardless of age, profession, or company—united by their connection to SAP. Through this activity, I’ve been able to connect with so many people, and I feel that the entire landscape of my life has changed.

chillSAP is a Japan-born community with the goal of helping everyone involved with SAP connect in a relaxed and enjoyable way.
Founded in 2019, we’ve hosted numerous events to date.

Event Highlight: SAP Anything Lightning Talk Festival
A 5-minute lightning talk event where any SAP-related topic is welcome.
The presentations are characterized by their free and flexible style, allowing participants to share ideas in a relaxed and creative way.

 

Event Highlight: SAP Inside Track Tokyo

Since 2019, I’ve been involved in organizing SAP Inside Track Tokyo (sitTokyo).
Although I’m not fully familiar with the details of other countries’ events, I believe Tokyo ranks among the top globally in terms of the number of sessions.
SAP Inside Track Tokyo 2019 finished a great success #Recap #sitTokyo 
SAP Inside Track Tokyo 2023 
SAP Inside Track Tokyo 2024 イベントサイト 
SAP Inside Track Tokyo 2025 Event Information 

We’ve also published recordings of past sessions on YouTube, so please feel free to check them out!
Youtube

By the way, I also occasionally speak at events.
In 2025, I gave a talk on the theme “ABAP Developer Capabilities with Joule.”
Please feel free to check it out if you're interested!
YouTube

 

(2) Attending SAP TechEd and Experiencing Inspiring Learning and Encounters

SAP TechEd has always been a place for me to reconnect with both technology and people.
I’ve attended multiple times, and each time has brought me fresh inspiration and motivation.

2018
I attended TechEd Las Vegas for the first time as a blogger.
Just eight months after starting my blog, I was invited by SAP Japan to join the event.
I was honestly surprised—“I can’t believe it’s me!”—but the experience on-site became a major turning point in both my career and my life.

2019
At TechEd Las Vegas, I hosted an informal meetup called “Sumikko Night.”
I took the initiative to gather Japanese participants and create a space for connection and conversation.
This experience of building a community space that transcended companies and roles became one of the foundations of my community activities.

2023
I attended TechEd Bangalore in person—the first on-site TechEd after the COVID-19 pandemic.
I was deeply impressed by the practical demos on SAP Build and AI-related sessions, as well as the energy and enthusiasm of the local participants.
Being able to directly interact with developers from around the world was incredibly stimulating, both technically and personally.



I also had the honor of speaking as a panelist during the closing session of SAP TechEd Japan, held in Tokyo.

2024
I participated in TechEd on Tour @ Melbourne (SAUG-x 2024).
The venue was spacious and comfortable, allowing me to fully concentrate on the sessions.
SAP Japan provided excellent support for Japanese attendees, which made the experience smooth and reassuring.

 

 

 

 

Recharging My Motivation Through TechEd

TechEd is a place that recharges my spirit—so much so that I feel, “This is what keeps me going for the year.”
Being able to attend sessions by well-known SAP Community members, whom I had only seen on social media or YouTube, was an unforgettable experience.

It was incredibly inspiring to meet these people in person and feel the energy of the global SAP community.
TechEd reminds me of the joy of learning and the power of connection—it’s a source of motivation that fuels me throughout the year.

Do any of you remember taking a photo with me? 🙋

 

 

 

Answers to Blog It Forward Questions

 

If you could go back to age 20, what would you study?
I would study English and IT fundamentals.
I believe I should have learned these properly back then—I'm currently studying them now!

Best lesson learned from your parents?
From my cheerful parents, I learned this valuable lesson:
“Take care of your own mood.”

 

Next Blog It Forward Participant

I’d like to pass the baton to Mino-san ( @Mino ), who co-manages the community with me here in Japan.
I’m always inspired by his intellectual curiosity and unwavering sense of purpose.
Please look forward to his Blog It Forward post!

 

In Closing

Starting with my blog SAP Sumikko, I’ve been fortunate to connect with many wonderful people.
I hope to continue contributing to and energizing the SAP community.
It’s truly an honor to be part of the Blog It Forward initiative.

Thank you so much for reading all the way through!

Below is a photo from my very first external speaking engagement in 2018.

entry.title: Differentiating DSA Violations from Common Moderation Issues
entry.content:
Next time you report inappropriate content on SAP Community, you’ll notice that we’ve introduced a new process for identifying why the moderation alert has been raised.

When we updated our moderation methods last year to comply with the Digital Services Act (DSA), we leaned toward a more formal approach for aligning with these new regulations. In doing so, however, we tended to lump all sorts of moderation reports under DSA. As a result, we lost much of the human touch essential to a helpful, cordial moderation program.

To give our moderators more flexibility – while ensuring that we continue to adhere to the law for true DSA cases (e.g., content deemed harmful and illegal under these EU rules) – we have modified the menus that members use when reporting inappropriate content.

The first step remains the same: You’ll still find the option for reporting inappropriate content from the dropdown menu next to posts, answers, comments, etc., throughout the site. (Here’s what you’ll see when reporting a question, for example.)

Selecting this option will bring you to a series of menus, as well as a text field, allowing you to provide details about why you’ve reported the content – while also indicating whether the content actually breaks DSA rules.

In most cases, you’ll simply choose “Non-DSA related alert to moderators” for the reason – as this selection applies to the majority of reports that our moderation team receives (for requests to move content to another area, remove/correct a tag, and so on).

If you pick “Non-DSA related alert to moderators” as the reason, the “DSA Specification” menu will remain grayed out. (Since the reason is unrelated to a DSA violation, no additional selection is required.) You’ll still have the option to enter additional information (in the “Details” field). For example, you can point out an incorrect tag (and propose a better one) before submitting the report by clicking the “Notify Moderator” button.

This information helps our moderators understand the nature of the issue and work with members quickly to fix the problem, minus the formality of DSA steps that require stiffly worded messages and legally sounding explanations. In other words, for non-DSA cases, the moderators can work with members in a capacity that doesn’t feel overly official, rebuilding the trust and connections associated with moderation before we instituted stricter rules under DSA.

In situations where something does violate the DSA, our moderation team will continue to follow DSA procedures. We only ask that you make certain that it’s a true DSA offense before reporting it as such.

When alerting the moderation team about a DSA violation, you’ll need to select one of the reasons beneath the dashed line (underneath “Non-DSA related alert to moderators”), such as “Illegal Or Harmful Speech” and “Unsafe And/Or Illegal Products.”

This action opens the “DSA Specification” menu, where you’ll need to select the item related to the reason. There are several to choose.

Since we have mapped these reasons and specifications to DSA systems (which is where we need to upload data about our DSA-related activities), we must make sure that we open and submit every DSA case accurately. You can help by selecting the right reason (distinguishing between non-DSA and DSA alerts) and DSA specification (in the event of actual DSA violations) carefully when reporting content that requires moderation.

Not sure which selection to make? You’ll see some helpful suggestions right next to the menus, providing guidance about what to select and why for common scenarios.

As an example, if you want to report spam, select “Violation of Terms of Use” for the reason and “Other” from the “DSA Specification” menu. (Remember to add some information in the details to help our moderators understand why you’re reporting the content.)

One last piece of important advice: Negative feedback and curt comments aren’t against the law, and they don’t qualify as harassment and hate speech under DSA regulations. To be more specific, as an example, DSA defines hate speech as “illegal incitement to violence and hatred based on protected characteristics.” Therefore, before reporting member comments as misconduct under DSA, consider whether they can be categorized as illegal speech. Per our Basic Etiquette and Tips for Participating in SAP Community guidelines, members should keep discourse civil and try to work out differences, reporting member comments only when they are truly harmful and in violation of DSA regulations. Disagreements and criticism are not grounds for moderator action – especially under DSA.

By differentiating non-DSA and DSA reports, we are taking steps to make moderation friendlier – freeing it from the rigid steps that we applied when we treated all alerts as DSA cases. At the same time, we’ll continue to ensure that SAP Community complies with DSA, protecting our site and our members from the illegal activities that the regulations cover.

entry.title: SAP Developer News 10th July, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION

SAP TechEd Community Talk and DemoJam Submissions

  • SAP TechEd Registration https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin.html
  • Community Talk Submission blogpost https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-teched-blog-posts/become-part-of-the-sap-teched-family-as-a-community-talk-speaker/ba-p/14103324
  • Community Talk Submission Form https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin/flow/sap/te25/cfpct/form/session
  • DemoJam Submission blogpost https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-teched-blog-posts/a-fan-favorite-is-back-in-berlin-demo-jam-sapteched-2025/ba-p/14103360
  • DemoJam Submission Form https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin/flow/sap/te25/cfpctdemojam/form/session

SAP Developer License 3.2 CAP

  • CAP License info in Capire https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/resources/cap-license

SAP CodeJam roadshow in Southeast Asia and India

  • SAP CodeJam roadshow in India: https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-codejam-blog-posts/sap-integration-suite-codejam-roadshow-in-india/ba-p/14110730

Transition from SAP Build Work Zone, Standard to SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/a-comprehensive-guide-to-transition-from-sap-build-work-zone-standard/ba-p/14141857

CAP MCP Plugin

  • Blog Post: https://medium.com/@simonvlaursen/introducing-cap-mcp-transform-your-sap-applications-into-ai-ready-systems-410a01fda5aa
  • GitHub: https://github.com/gavdilabs/cap-mcp-plugin

Code Connect 2025

  • Code Connect Page: https://code-connect.dev/ 

CHAPTER TITLES

0:00 Intro

0:06 Code Connect 2025

3:20 SAP Developer License 3.2 CAP

7:04 SAP TechEd Community Talk and DemoJam Submissions

10:14 CAP MCP Plugin – AI with Ease

10:45  Transition from SAP Build Work Zone, Standard to SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition

12:18 SAP CodeJam roadshow in Southeast Asia and India

TRANSCRIPTION :

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for July the 10th, 2025.

[DJ, AJAY NICO & VITALI] Hi there, and welcome from St. Leon Rote in Germany, just down the road from the mothership in Waldorf. We're here at Code Connect 2025. It's Wednesday. It's been an amazing week so far, starting with, on Monday, what, Ajay? hello, everyone. Welcome. And on Monday, we had two Code Jams running in parallel, one for cap and one for ui5 and we had jam-packed rooms and it was really exciting so to see all of you there and it was a very good weather as well over over to you nico thanks yeah so the day after on tuesday we had ui5 con and my personal highlight was meeting many of you the developers and talk tech and also my to-do list of things i want to try out is getting longer and longer the longer of the week gets there's just so much inspiration out here so that was very cool and what happened today dj what happened today that's wednesday was recap recap 2025 um i love this event i love code connect generally but specifically recap again just like nico meeting you folks but learning from you folks learning from everybody everybody from the sessions from the corridor conversations it's just humbling to see so many big brains and so many humble people so many modest people here at the event and we've got something special tomorrow as well as part of the code connect event what is it vitaly so for the very first time code connect family is getting a new child which is HANA techcon and we are really looking for that because the idea came to us last year during the code connect and we really wanted to get hana into the family of all the other technologies at sap so probably you're looking this on friday and we are recording this on Soon, we talked about hosting SAP events, and we've never stopped. It's wonderful to be with the community and see the difference we can make in the lives of each participant.

Now focus in Marssel´s question:

With S/4HANA, RISE with SAP, and BTP evolving rapidly, what do you think is essential for SAP clients to stay ahead in technology and digital transformation in the coming years?

For SAP customers to stay ahead in digital transformation, continuous evolution withSAP S/4HANA, RISE with SAP e SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is crucial. This is no longer an option, but a necessity.

Keep Clean Core : Minimize customizations and use standard S/4HANA functionality to facilitate upgrades and innovations and Adopt industry best practices. Using Rise with full  package ( Signavio, BTP, HANA Cloud and business process) 

Invest in training and have a huge governance. Invest in IA to help the Company transformation .

I would like to Blog it forward to  @Jonys_Arcanjo , He is new SAP Champion as me. And my question is what´s is next step as SAP Champion, how this position impact your life?

entry.title: SAP Community Team Spotlight: Laura Schmitz - July 2025 Edition
entry.content:
You might have seen our iterations of recognizing active authors (one / two / three / four / five / six)  in SAP Community. We also want to introduce the team behind the SAP Community platform. This month we want to introduce @lauraschmitz  to you which I interviewed recently. Read more about how she got started and what her day to day looks like behind the scenes of the SAP Community.


Marco Santos (MS): I'm super happy that you've decided to join us today. Laura, thank you so much for being here. It's a great pleasure to feature you as our next Community Team Member Spotlight on SAP Community.

Laura Schmitz: Thank you, Marco! I'm also very delighted to be part of this interview. I really appreciate the opportunity.

MS: Awesome. All right, let’s start with an easy one. How did you originally get involved with the SAP Community?

Laura Schmitz: I got involved with the SAP Community through my second role at SAP. I originally joined the company as a working student in 2018, supporting the learning organization. After finishing my studies in 2020, I applied internally for a Community Advocate role and that’s when I really started getting to know the SAP Community. I’d heard about it now and then in my first role, but I hadn’t really interacted with it until I joined the team.

MS: That’s great to hear! So, you've been on the team for a few years now, but could you tell us a bit more about your current role on the community team and what your day-to-day typically looks like?

Laura Schmitz: Sure! My current role is Community Event Lead, which means I focus on the strategy and overall concept of community events globally. A big part of my job is helping event organizers by supporting them with everything they need to run successful events for their local communities. I also make sure that these efforts are aligned with our broader SAP Community strategy.

MS: Sounds like a big responsibility!

Laura Schmitz: It definitely keeps things exciting! There’s no such thing as a completely typical day, but a common task is reviewing applications from people who are interested in becoming event organizers. I run interviews with them, guide them through onboarding, and ensure any new locations they represent are properly added to our platform.

MS: So you’re kind of a matchmaker for new communities?

Laura: That’s a good way to put it! I also proactively look into regions we haven’t reached yet and try to find engaged community members who might want to help build something there. Beyond that, I stay in regular contact with existing organizers by discussing their upcoming events, helping them with financial or promotional support, and looking for opportunities for our community team to be present at those events as well.

MS: That already sounds like a very full day! All right, let’s move on to the next question. Can you share a particularly memorable moment from your time working with the community?

Laura Schmitz: That would definitely be attending my very first SAP Inside Track. It was in ‘s-Hertogenbosch, in the Netherlands, back in 2022.

It was really special for me because I had joined the community team during COVID. Everyone kept telling me how amazing these events were, and I saw pictures and posts, but I never truly understood what made them so great until I experienced one myself.

The vibe was just incredible! So casual and fun, but also filled with value and genuine knowledge-sharing. And what stood out the most was how welcoming everyone was. People were just happy to connect, learn, and share with each other. I’ll never forget that experience of finally understanding what community is about.

MS: Yeah, I definitely agree. Meeting people in person: nothing beats that for really understanding what a community is all about.

Now, moving on to the next question: You're in contact with many event organizers and community members. How do you stay in touch with community needs and feedback?

Laura Schmitz: Since my focus is mainly on community events, most of the feedback I receive comes directly from the event organizers. They know they can always reach out, often via email, but we also have a dedicated private group on the SAP Community platform. It’s our main space for communication, resource sharing, and best practice exchange. And it also acts as a feedback channel.

In addition to that, we meet on a quarterly basis with all organizers globally. During those sessions, we share updates, but more importantly, we listen to their needs and concerns. We try our best to address their feedback, even if we can’t act on every single request. For me, having that close, open, and transparent relationship with the organizers is really essential.

Marco Santos: That’s great to hear. Sounds like a very organic and ongoing way to stay in touch with what’s happening on the ground. All right, next up: what do you enjoy most about working on the SAP Community?

Laura Schmitz: It’s definitely the people! Connecting with people. Of course, I spend a lot of time being online, behind the scenes and working on the platform, but what really brings me joy is the one-on-one interaction. Whether it's working with a group of organizers in a specific city or hearing about someone’s journey, those connections are what make this role so meaningful.

Every local community is different. Every organizer team has their own way of doing things. That diversity, that authenticity, is what I find so special about this work.

MS: That’s great to hear and a lovely answer! We’ve talked a lot about the past and how you got involved in the community. Now, let’s talk about the future: What’s one thing you’d love to see more of in the SAP Community going forward?

Laura Schmitz: More in-person connections among community members, and continuous relationship building between our team and community members. That’s definitely something I’d love to see continuing and growing. And also adding new locations to the map, we still have some regions that aren’t yet represented in our community. A great example is the Middle East, which has recently started getting involved with their very first SAP CodeJam in Dubai. Now, the organizer wants to establish more community events in the region and connect people on a regular basis. I’d love to see that trend continue. The more local communities we can support, the better.

MS: Sounds like a solid plan. More events, more locations leads to more connection! Okay, and now to wrap things up: Is there anything else you’d like to share with the audience? Anything we didn’t cover that you’d like to add?

Laura Schmitz: I’d like to encourage community members to get active and to engage in their local community - by joining a community event near you or organize your own. There’s a common misconception that you need to be a professional organizer, an expert, or someone with years of experience to lead something meaningful in your community. But the truth is - anyone can start. Real impact often begins with simple actions: a shared interest and a handful of people who just want to connect. And if this this resonates with you and you feel inspired to take that first step, we’d love to hear from you, so reach out and let’s explore what we can build together.

MS: That’s a perfect way to close it out. Thank you so much, Laura, for joining me today: sharing your journey, your day-to-day, and your vision for the future of the SAP Community. It was great having you here.

Laura Schmitz: Thanks again, Marco. It’s been a pleasure!

entry.title: Raja Gupta
entry.content:
More about Raja Gupta in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Raja Gupta
Location (City, Country): Bangalore, India
Occupation: Solution Architect, SAP

 


Raja, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

I'm Raja Gupta, a solution architect with over 17 years of experience in SAP. Throughout my career, I’ve led multiple implementation projects and currently work with SAP Partners to co-innovate and build solutions using BTP and AI.

I'm also the author of several SAP-focused books, a regular speaker at global SAP events, and an active contributor to the SAP community through mentoring, blogging, and training. You can find the list of all my books on SAP-Press site  and read of my blogs on SAP Community.

What truly drives me is the joy of sharing knowledge - whether it’s through writing, speaking, or engaging with my 43K+ LinkedIn followers on topics around SAP and AI.

I’m based out of Bangalore. When I’m not working, I’m usually spending time with my kids and family, reading, or planning our next family trip.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

I specialize in SAP BTP, SAP Business AI, Joule, Generative AI, and related technologies.

I work closely with SAP Partners to onboard them to SAP Business AI and Joule, guiding them in building real-world solutions. I deliver technical workshops and enablement sessions across various SAP Business AI and BTP topics, often customized for partner-specific needs.

My day typically involves hands-on collaboration with partners, activating SAP Business AI, addressing technical challenges, and enabling partners to adopt SAP’s latest innovations effectively.

Outside of that, I regularly write, train, and mentor within the SAP ecosystem, sharing insights through blogs and community platforms.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?

I started engaging with the SAP Community in 2016, when I published my first blog post. What began as a simple attempt to share a few thoughts quickly turned into something much more meaningful — I found a space where people supported each other and where learning didn’t feel one-sided.

Over time, I’ve learned a lot from this community, and that naturally created a sense of responsibility to contribute in return. Whether it’s writing blog posts, speaking at events, or simply answering a question, I’ve seen the real impact of open knowledge-sharing.

As someone who spends a lot of time delivering trainings, and enablement sessions, the SAP Champion role felt like a natural extension of what I already do. It allows me to stay connected with the community, support peer learning, and continue contributing in a more focused and visible way.


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

Each morning, I spend the first 30 minutes of my workday either reading something new or drafting content to share with the community. This small but consistent routine keeps me in sync with what’s happening, and also pushes me to contribute back regularly.

I’ve made the SAP Community a regular part of my learning routine. I follow a set of topics closely and make it a habit to visit their pages frequently to stay updated. I’ve also subscribed to SAP newsletters and topic-specific notifications. These notifications helps me to check in and explore new posts, questions, and discussions.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

Here are three things that have worked well for me and might help others get more value from the SAP Community:

Follow topics that genuinely interest you.
Don’t try to keep up with everything. Pick a few areas you're working on or curious about and make it a habit to check their pages regularly. The focused approach helps you stay updated without getting overwhelmed.

Build a simple weekly rhythm.
You don’t need hours. Even spending 15–30 minutes a day reading a blog post, answering a question, or sharing a quick thought can keep you connected and sharp. I personally begin my day with this and it keeps me in sync with what's moving in the ecosystem.

Look beyond the screen.
There’s real value in attending SAP Community events for example SAP Inside Track, CodeJam etc. These are great places to meet others working on similar things, ask questions you wouldn’t post online, and build lasting connections.

Raja's question to you:
If you could give one piece of advice to someone new to the SAP Community, what would it be — and why?

entry.title: Antonio de Ancos
entry.content:
More about Antonio de Ancos in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Antonio de Ancos
Location (City, Country): Madrid, Spain
Occupation: Consultant and Instructor

 

 


Antonio, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

I am a lifelong learner and an “occasional” teacher. I believe we live in an age where all kinds of knowledge are at our fingertips, which can sometimes be overwhelming; that’s why my main work is helping others learn faster and more easily. I enjoy sharing good meals with friends, playing sports, and diving into a great book.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

I started in 1997 programming ABAP, specifically in the HR module. From there I explored the entire functional side without ever leaving the technical world behind, which led me to wrestling with SAP BTP since its early days (HCP, SCP…). I’ve been an official SAP instructor for over 20 years in both HCM and Technology areas.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?


I didn’t do anything special to become an SAP Champion; someone nominated me, and here I am 😉. I suppose it has something to do with the content I’ve been creating in Spanish over the years—through my blog (www.aancos.com), social media, and a couple of podcasts where I share my professional journey (www.memoriasdeunconsultor.com) and chat with ecosystem experts (www.hablamosdesap.com), including several SAP Champions.


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

In SAP Community I learn from others, since there are people with deep expertise in many of the areas I’m interested in. I find it always easier to learn when someone guides you, although I don’t follow a strict routine.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

I think it’s important to clearly identify a few key thought leaders and accept that you can’t keep up with everything—you risk getting lost in the vast ocean of knowledge. Often, less is more; knowing where to focus is essential.

Antonio's question to you:
Here’s my thought-provoking question: English is undoubtedly the universal language in the technical world, and in SAP in particular (with all due respect to German), so why not create more content for the Spanish-speaking community in their own language?

entry.title: SAP BTP
entry.content:
SAP BTP: Рушій цифрової трансформації для бізнесу

Чи знаєте ви? SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) є основою цифрової трансформації для понад 24 000 підприємств у всьому світі, включаючи 90 зі 100 найбільших компаній світу!

🌟Клієнти BTP демонструють кращі результати: на 3% нижчі операційні витрати та в 4 рази вища цифрова зрілість порівняно зі звичайними клієнтами SAP.

🔄Ці організації обробляють неймовірні $51 трильйон торгівельного обороту щорічно, з вражаючим охопленням галузей:

  • 96% доходів у роздрібній торгівлі споживчими товарами
  • 90% доходів автомобільної галузі
  • 83% доходів галузі товарів для дому

💼Середньостатистичний клієнт SAP використовує 11 продуктів BTP, а підприємства Азійсько-Тихоокеанського регіону лідирують у впровадженні із середнім показником 19 продуктів!

Дізнавайтесь більше про BTP на нашому сайті.

 

#SAPUkraine30#SAPCommunityKyiv #SAPІнновації #SAPBTP #SAPUkraine #SAP

entry.title: 🚀 Get Ready for SAP AIDevCon 2025 in Gurugram, India! 🚀

🚀Get Ready for SAP AIDevCon 2025 in Gurugram, India! 🚀

Exciting news for AI enthusiasts across India! SAP AIDevCon 2025 is coming to SAP Labs, Gurugram, and it's unlike anything you've seen before.

This isn't just an SAP Community event; it's an immersive experience designed to supercharge your AI skills. Here's what awaits you:

  • Hands-on Training: Get expertly trained on the best AI services and tools from SAP BTP, whether you're a seasoned developer or completely new to the game.

  • Dedicated Mentorship: We'll assign you mentors who will guide you through every step of your learning journey.

  • Real-world Problem Solving: You'll think and plan for a real-world problem or challenge, then design a cutting-edge solution using the AI tools you've mastered.

  • Team-based Solutions: Collaborate with your own team to design and build innovative solutions, all while enjoying a sip of coffee!

We're also opening this up to college students and lecturers, providing access to invaluable, no-cost, industry- and job-oriented SAP certifications.

Here's how it'll work:

  • Phase 1: Fill the Survey here (Complete by July 22nd!)

  • Phase 2: Online Session (Mandatory instructions before the event - Dates will be shared soon!)

  • Phase 3: In-person SAP AIDevCon 2025 (At SAP Labs, Gurugram - Dates will be shared soon!)

It's crucial to complete Phases 1 & 2 to get your exclusive invite PASS. Simply registering or showing interest won't guarantee a seat.

Just bring your learning enthusiasm and your laptop! I'll be your "AIDevBuddy" to help you at every step.

Important Note: This event is open to participants from across India. However, please be aware that no travel, boarding, or lodging will be offered.

Join Us as a Sponsor or Mentor!

  • Are you a Sponsor passionate about the future of AI? Show your interest with #AIDevConSponsor!

  • Are you an AIDevMentor eager to help the SAP Community build stronger AI solutions that improve lives? Use #AIDevConMentor and we'll reach out to you!

What are you waiting for? Fill the survey and stay tuned for more details!

Feel free to ask any questions in the comments below!

#SAPAIDevCon @SAP #SAPCommunity

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite CodeJam roadshow in India - recap
entry.content:
What an eventful week it was! (No pun intended)..... Together with @ajay_soreng, we did one SAP CodeJam per day - 3 different cities (Mumbai, Hyderabad, and Bengaluru), 5 different locations, 3 different topics (SAP Integration Suite, SAP Build Process Automation, and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh).

Everything was planned to perfection but I had a mental misstep. I mistakenly thought that there was a visa on arrival when traveling to India when in reality it requires applying for an e-visa. Unfortunately, I only found this when I was doing my check-in - Saturday, exactly 12 hours before my flight, a bit late right? I immediately applied for an e-visa but given that it was a Saturday I had to wait till Monday for a resolution. Don't get me wrong, the e-visa process is really good and fast but you can't expect much when you end up applying for it too late.

The adventure only starts here...I joined the first event remotely, from Madrid. Once I receive the e-visa approval, I had 4.5 hours to catch the next plane leaving Madrid heading to India. The second event, I also joined it remotely, but this time from Abu Dhabi. The plane touched ground at 06:35, after going through security, I immediate started searching for a quiet place to join the 2nd CodeJam of the week. Fortunately, I found one :-). Straight after the event, I boarded a plane to Hyderabad - not kidding, I was walking to the gate as we were wrapping up the event. I closed my laptop a minute before boarding. Finally, I made it to Hyderabad Tuesday night and I was able to join the last three events in-person. I sincerely want to apologise to the attendees of the first two events as I wasn't able to be there in-person but it was great meeting you virtually; also, doing the event remotely would have not been possible if it wasn't for the great help and support from @ajay_soreng and @Shilpa_Shankar - Thanks to you both!

Apart from the physical badges (stickers) that many of the attendees got. All attendees of the different SAP CodeJams will get a special SAP Community badge for attending the events 🪪.

 

 

Mumbai

In Mumbai we did the Connecting systems and services using SAP Integration Suite CodeJam at Colgate office. Thanks Colgate for hosting!

We recently introduced a new exercise where we interact with Slack and send notifications from Cloud Integration to Slack. It was exciting to see many attendees posting their notifications even after the event finished.

Hyderabad

In Hyderabad it was all about SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. We ran the Event-driven integrations CodeJam at two different locations. Thanks Mindset and Infosys for hosting the events. I joined the first one remotely from Abu Dhabi and finally in-person for the second event. 

Bengaluru

Last city part of the SAP Integration Suite CodeJam roadshow. At Bengaluru, we ran the new SAP Build: Event-based processes and also the Connecting systems and services with SAP Integration Suite CodeJams at SAP Labs Bengaluru and Mindset Consulting, thanks for hosting. We were fortunate enough to be joined by the entire SAP Developer Advocates team based in India ( @sheenamk, @eshrinivasan, @Rekha_DR, @Shilpa_Shankar), as well as by @acharyaw - PM for SAP Build Process Automation.

 

Food

Last but certainly not least... all the lovely food that we enjoyed as part of the roadshow. Thanks to all the hosts.... the food was amazing everywhere haha.

Lots of lessons learned from the mental misstep and there might be cool things and opportunities coming up thanks to it. Also, this wouldn't have been possible without @ajay_soreng's help organising the events and supporting me while I was remotely - Thanks!

entry.title: Welcome Message – SAP Community Joinville, Brazil
entry.content:
Hello everyone, and welcome to the SAP Community Group in Joinville, Brazil!

Joinville is a city located in the south of Brazil, in the state of Santa Catarina. It has a rich historical background, originally founded in 1851 as part of a land grant from the French royal family to Prince François Ferdinand of Orléans. Soon after, Joinville became home to a large wave of German, Swiss, and Norwegian immigrants, which shaped its culture, architecture, and traditions that remain vibrant to this day.

Often called the “City of Flowers” and “City of Princes,” Joinville is also famous for hosting the Joinville Dance Festival, one of the largest dance festivals in the world. Its combination of European heritage and Brazilian warmth creates a unique cultural atmosphere.

Today, Joinville is recognized as one of Brazil’s most important industrial and technological hubs, leading innovation in sectors such as software development, automotive, and manufacturing. This thriving economy has helped position the city as a strategic center for digital transformation and SAP-related opportunities.

This group is created to connect SAP professionals, students, and enthusiasts in the region, fostering collaboration, networking, and continuous learning. We invite you to share insights, ask questions, and contribute to building a strong and dynamic SAP community here in Joinville.

Welcome aboard – let’s grow together!

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Munich 2025 | Call for Speakers 📢 #sitMUC25
entry.content:
The SAP Inside Track Munich (#sitMUC) is back ...

Dear SAP Community,

On October 11th, the SAP community will gather once again in Garching for a day full of learning, sharing, and connecting .. and we want you to be part of it.

Whether you're deep into ABAP, building apps on SAP BTP, working with Fiori, S/4HANA, or Analytics, exploring DevOps in SAP, or shaping business processes, driving change in projects, or navigating transformation from a consulting perspective, your insights matter. Our audience comes from all corners of the SAP universe: developers, consultants, architects, product experts, and curious newcomers. That’s why we’re looking for diverse session ideas: technical deep dives, lessons learned from projects, open-source initiatives, or even side projects that others can learn from. It doesn’t have to be perfect or polished. If it’s real and relevant to the community, it belongs on stage.

Important dates and submission process:

  • Call opens: July 24st
  • Submission deadline: August 30th
  • Speaker selection: by September 5th
  • Please submit your proposal using our online form:
    sitmuc.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com

There are various session types for your submissions:

  • Short Presentation (20 min)
  • Presentation (40 min)
    you will present a topic to the audience demos, theory, live coding, or anything else that suits your expertise
  • Marketplace
    you will share your topic in a “marketplace” breakout session where everyone is welcome to walk around, visit the various stands, and interact

What we’re looking for:

  • On-site only we’ll be together in person!
  • No marketing pitches – just genuine value for the community

We’d love to hear your ideas whether you’re a seasoned speaker or presenting for the very first time. Let’s make #sitMUC25 another unforgettable community event.

If you're unsure about your topic, format, or how to present it no worries! Just drop us an email at sitmuc.orga@gmail.com, we're happy to help. Or better yet: join our next Stammtisch meetup (14.08.), and let’s chat about your session idea in person.

Let’s build this day together. Bring your voice, your story, your topic. We can’t wait to hear it!

Best regards,
sitMUC Orga team

entry.title: A Look Back At CodeConnect 2025
entry.content:
A Look Back At CodeConnect 2025

It's been almost 2 weeks now since I participated in the 2025 CodeConnect event, which was actually my first in-person CodeConnect ever.
I would've participated in person sooner, but getting tickets is akin to trying to get the most popular item on Black Friday, it requires speed, precision and luck!

But enough rambling about the tickets! Let's take a look back at my journey to CodeConnect 2025.

UI5Con 2025

I'm going to skip the very first day of CodeConnect, mainly due to it being spent in a car for 16 hours, as me and my colleagues made the journey from the northern part of Jutland to St. Leon Rot.
So for us, the conference didn't start until day 2 with UI5Con, and that was some start.

Upon arrival at the building, it was straight into networking and trying to decide what sessions were most interesting to participate in.
We ended up doing a divide and conquer strategy in our group to get the most out of the day, with of course a focus on getting to the hands-on sessions.

My day quickly became side-tracked as I caught up with both old and new faces in my effort to connect with all the other developers present at the event.
Which, to be honest, for a mostly backend/cloud guy like me wasn't all bad. While I do enjoy a tango with the frontend from time to time, my heart belongs to what goes on behind the scenes.

But I did catch a lot of good talks still; so here are my take-aways from the first real day at CodeConnect:

  • Ownership of styling is slowly being handed back to the developer, meaning we can now make proper custom components for UI5 that style correctly with the themes such as Horizon.
  • Still no clear release date for UI5 v2, but we do have a legacy free 1.136 out there now that we can utilize and prepare with
  • Promise for UI5 developers that keep in line with the UI5 Linter, that their code will be lift and shift (i.e. go use the linter asap!)
  • The UI5 repository has completed its moving phase and is now living in its own repository
  • Accessibility, much like everywhere else in the developer space at the moment, is the talk of the town, and SAP is doing a lot of improvements on this front
  • 2 test runners were presented as the replacements for the deprecated Karma runner. I know that I am leaning the most towards the WDI5 route due to it working as a more complete suite.
  • Webcomponents are the main focus going forward, and even though there is no timestamp on it, it seems like it will replace many of our current components going forward

That was pretty much my experience and take-aways for the first day there, and with it we wrapped up the UI5Con with some great food before heading back to the hotel.
The next for me, I knew would be something special.

reCAP 2025

Second day for me at CodeConnect started out with a great opening key note by Daniel Hutzel. Although he ran out of time by the end, I wish we could've listened to him for just a little while longer.

The key take-away of this keynote however, was extremely clear. Over the last year, the focus by the CAP team has really been on minimizing the footprint of the CAP/CDS install while optimizing and improving the feature set of the framework.
And from what we were presented, that definitely looked like it came out as a success. As a developer that uses CAP on a daily basis, both for plugin development and end-user projects, I can definitely say that I have enjoyed the improvements so far.

So a kudos to the CAP team is definitely in order on this! (Now we just need it to be open source!)

Unfortunately, I did not have as much time to participate in the many sessions of this day, as much like the day before, the event became more of a networking experience.
The sessions I did catch however, were absolutely great and definitely something that you should catch up on if you have the chance;

  • Both sessions by Mike Zaschka (just always a good listen and everybody loves open source!)
  • CAP Tools session by Christian Georgi (because you cannot be a good developer without knowing your tools)
  • Server-side Pre-rendering by Volker Buzek and Wouter Lemaire (a great session with insights into another great open source initiative)
  • CAP Best vs Bad Practices by Daniel Hutzel
  • Gain a superpower by learning how to harness the CDS REPL by DJ Adams (seriously, learn REPL)

While these were the only sessions I managed to catch, I did however experience something extremely important during the reCAP event, and that was the community.

I got to connect with so many great people and talk about the passion of this side of the industry, and the love we all share for opens source technologies.

I even got the chance to appear on the SAP Developer News to share my own open source contribution (MCP Plugin for CAP).

And that is something I wouldn't trade for anything.

You Should Attend

I hope it is clear from my post here that going to CodeConnect is an experience, no matter how you plan it. It is an event filled with great people and some great discussions around the subjects we all work with on a daily basis.

Never in a million years would I have imagined that going to CodeConnect would have resulted in me getting to participate in the SAP Developer News, nor that I would get to have great open discussions with other open source contributors.
It is definitely worth it, so if you get the chance I highly recommend that you participate!

Hopefully I will get the chance to contribute to the speakers list next year!

entry.title: The Return of SAP Community Voice!
entry.content:
Last seen in October of last year, SAP Community Voice was our online newsletter, replacing the email version that had gone out to subscribers for many years. Now after a long hiatus, we’re bringing the online edition back!

SAP Community Voice highlights popular posts, important community news, upcoming events, and more. If you’re interested in hot SAP Community content and announcements, look no further. You’ll find it all summarized here.

This edition covers items from the last four weeks or so, and future editions will aim to deliver even more timely information on a regular basis. Make sure to subscribe to the SAP Community Voice label so you don’t miss any issues of our online newsletter!

 

Featured Content

 

Heartiest Congratulations to Our Newest SAP Champions!

SAP Champions include some of the best and brightest SAP Community members, and this month, my colleague @KatherineKenneally welcomes eight new people to the program. To learn more about them (and about the program), check out her post and find out how you can connect with SAP Champions in your region!

Read the blog post

 

The Complete Guide to Calling Actions in UI5 with Custom Code

Prolific SAP Community contributor @Marian_Zeis has published a blog post that will help you trigger OData actions and functions from UI5 like a pro -- no matter whether you’re using SAP Fiori elements or going purely freestyle (v2 or v4). This guide walks through every official API, shows exactly when to pick each one, and more.

Read the blog post

 

SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud

In this post, SAP’s @Ammar_Naji points out that SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud are core components of SAP Business Data Cloud -- and that they soon won’t be on the list of eligible services under certain subscriptions. He explains what customers can do to prepare for these changes.

Read the blog post

 

Tree View in the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

Implementing a tree view in the ABAP RESTful application programming model requires different entities, and author @Vivek_Sahu_21 covers how you can show structured, hierarchical data -- in a parent-child format -- that UI applications and analytics tools can consume easily, providing a smooth user experience.

Read the blog post

 

Community News

 

“Blog It Forward” Is Back and Better Than Ever!

Blog It Forward is one of the longest-running initiatives in our community, dating all the way back to 2012 with this post from my colleague @moshenaveh. SAP Champion @Sandra_Solis brought the series back earlier this year with this post, and since then, several other members have contributed their own posts. The series allows members to introduce themselves while nominating other peers to participate, bringing the community closer together. Check out the Blog It Forward label to find all of the latest posts in this series, subscribe to the label to get updates when new posts appear, and consider writing one of your own!

 

Differentiating DSA Violations from Common Moderation Issues

We have taken steps to make our moderation process friendlier while ensuring that SAP Community continues to comply with the Digital Services Act (DSA). In this recent post, we outline the steps that members now should take when reporting inappropriate content to our moderation team, differentiating between common issues (e.g., incorrect tags) and true DSA violations.

 

Basic Etiquette and Tips for Participating in SAP Community

We are expanding the knowledge base in the Welcome Corner with new resources meant to help members get the most out of their SAP Community experience. In the latest post, we cover the type of behavior we expect from members, offer advice for friendly member interactions, indicate when to notify moderators, and more. Whether you’re a long-time community member or just getting started, you’ll benefit from the guidance in this document.

 

Upcoming Events

 

Registration Is Live for SAP TechEd 2025

SAP TechEd is scheduled for November, and this year, we’re building a hybrid experience that brings together the best of both worlds -- a full in-person experience in Berlin and a customized virtual experience for audiences around the world. Learn more about this exciting event in this blog post from SAP's @cecihuergo and register today for SAP TechEd!

 

Find SAP CodeJam Events in Your Region

SAP CodeJam events bring together developers who want hands-on learning about SAP technology, solutions, and applications. In August, you can attend SAP CodeJam sessions in Lima (Peru), Mexico City, Bogota (Colombia), and Wroclaw (Poland). Visit the SAP CodeJam activity group to learn more about these events, and check out the full list of upcoming events.
